speaker: miki meek
utterance: It's already been five years since the disaster.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: If this voice reaches you, please listen.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Sometimes I don't know what I'm living for.

speaker: issei's father
utterance: (CRYING) Issei, [JAPANESE]

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Issei, please let me hear you call me Papa.

speaker: issei's father
utterance: (CRYING) Papa, [JAPANESE]

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Even though I built a new house--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Dad? Mom?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Mine and Issei.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: --without all of you, it's meaningless.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I want to hear your reply, but I can't hear anything.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: He hangs up the phone, takes off his glasses, and covers his eyes with his hands.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I'm sorry.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I'm so sorry I couldn't save you.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: There's a couple phrases I heard callers tell the dead, again and again. Shinpai shina, don't worry about us. And ganbatteiru, which basically means, I'm doing my very best. I'm enduring.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: In Japan, ganbatteiru-- it's a catchall slogan for slogging through life's many challenges, no matter how tiny or big. From trying to pass a test at school, to grieving, you hear it all the time for everything. In the phone booth, ganbatteiru, and shinpai shina-- these are key phrases to reassure the dead that the living, the people left behind, they're doing OK, even if they're not.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: People don't want to worry or burden their loved ones, even dead loved ones. Because most Japanese are Buddhist, and generally believe that when someone dies, they're not suddenly relieved of all their earthly concerns. They're not automatically in heaven, happy and carefree. Many people believe that if the dead see a family member suffering, they can't let go of their earthly life. They hesitate to cross to the other side, and end up stuck in a no-man's land.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I heard these reassurances in a call from a 15-year-old kid named Ren Kozaki, to his dad. He arrived at the phone booth after spending four hours on public transportation by himself. Ren lives in a city much farther north that wasn't affected as much by the tsunami.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: But his dad was a truck driver who drove all over Japan. And in a last-minute schedule change, he got sent on a route that took him along the coast when the tsunami hit. He's been missing ever since. Ren went into the phone booth wearing a red backpack.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: And what he does in his call-- you hear him signaling to his dad that it's OK. He should keep moving on into the after world.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Dad?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: The four of us are doing fine.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: We're ganbatteiru.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: You don't need to worry about us. Shinpai shina.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Dad, are you doing OK?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I do have one question I want to ask you.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Why did you die? Why did it have to be you, dad?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Why just me?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I've always wondered--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Why am I the only one who is different from everyone else?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Anyways, please be found quickly.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Where are you now?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: They never found anything of you.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I wanted to talk with you again.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Ren left the booth. In late February, he came back with his entire family-- his mom, younger brother, and sister. They all drove down to Otsuchi together. And when they got to the phone booth, at first, they kind of awkwardly hung out in front of it. So to break the ice, Ren walks in and places the first call to their dad. He tells him--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I brought everyone with me today.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Bye. When Ren walks out, his family laughs. They say--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: --that was so fast. Ren shoots back--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: It was just a quick report to Dad, that I brought everyone with me today. Next up are Ren's little brother and sister, who are 12 and 14 years old.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: They go into the booth together. And the sister is talking and laughing nervously.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: What am I supposed to say? What should I tell them?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Wait, wait, don't leave me alone in here.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: The sister picks up the phone. And let me just say, the mom told the film crew that this is a girl who has not said a single word about her dad to anyone since he went missing five years ago. So she picks up the phone and starts to cry.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: She asks her brother again, when should I talk to him about? Her little brother's name is Riku, and he tells her--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Say what you wanted to tell him.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: She says--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Are you trying to make me laugh, Riku? Riku says--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: No, I'm not.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Then she finally starts talking to her dad. The conversation is all over the place, and she's crying so hard, she can barely talk.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Dad, I'm so sorry I always used to say you were stinky.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: What happen to your promise to buy me a violin?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Now I'll have to buy one myself.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Her little brother, who sticks close to her, he encourages her to keep going. He says--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: What else? So she tells her dad--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I started tennis in junior high school. I'm not in the top eight.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I want to be in the top eight our last tournament.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Please cheer for me.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I got hooked on this boy band, the Johnnys, when I was in my first year of junior high. I'm still hooked.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: They both say--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: --goodbye. They come out of the booth together.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Now it's their mom's turn. Her kids tell her, itterashai.

speaker: riku
utterance: Itterashai.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Have a good trip.

speaker: ren's mother
utterance: Itterashai.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Good luck. Ren, the oldest, he bows and waves to her. She walks in, picks up the phone, and lets out a big sigh.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Where should I start?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I feel like you're still alive-- somewhere.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: We had so many things we wanted to do together.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Over the phone, we always said to each other, are you alive? Yes, I'm alive.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: It was our password between the two of us, wasn't it?

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I can't ask you that anymore.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Come back.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: We, all four of us together, we will be waiting.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Bye.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: After she comes out, the family lingers outside the phone booth for a while.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: This was literally the first time they'd all talked about their dad together, since the tsunami happened five years ago. The youngest, Riku-- he sat quietly on a bench, with his head in his hands. The night before his dad disappeared, they went to a public bath together. His mom and older siblings tell him--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Riku, you don't need to keep your feelings in. Go ahead and cry when you want to. Ren, the oldest, gently teases him. He says--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: See? He can't stop crying. Mom says yeah, but--

speaker: miki meek
utterance: --he held back until now.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: It's OK, because you held back. You endured until now.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: The sister then hands Riku her handkerchief.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: The mom says her kids, we were all about to fall apart. We were so broken. We didn't think we could make it through. And maybe that's why we never talked about dad until now. But talking to him on the phone today, it changed something.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Miki Meek is one of the producers of our program. Thanks to NHK Sendai, who recorded all this, and shared it with us. Coming up, two brothers in their 80s have a last chance to talk to each other before they die. And neither wants to take it. That's in a minute from Chicago Public Radio, when our program continues.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: It's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. Today's program-- "One Last Thing Before I Go," stories that are about-- well, they're about what power do words have in the face of death? We've arrived at Act Two of our program.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Act Two, Uncle's Keeper. So in the first act of our program, people kind of defied death by making small talk-- and some talk that was not so small-- with their dead relatives.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: In this act, somebody wants to do something very similar-- make a connection that seemed impossible between people. Except in this story, all the relatives are alive, which you'd think would make it super easy. This story comes from Jonathan Goldstein.

utterance: Hello?

utterance: Hey, Dad?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Hi, Jonny.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Hey, how you doing?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Good, you?

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Good, good. Gut Yontif.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Shana tova.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Chag Sameach.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Chag Sameach.

utterance: What's that mean?

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: I'm not sure.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Oh, oh.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: This is my father, Buzz. I'm calling him at his home in Montreal. And the reason we're talking crazy talk is because it's Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, which seems as good a day as any to talk with him about forgiveness.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: So I wanted to--

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Yes.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: I wanted to ask you something. And I just wanted to gauge your interest.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: How-- how would you feel about paying your brother Sheldon a visit?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: I have no feelings about it. I'm not really interested.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: You're not?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: No.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: My father, Buzz, is 80. And his brother, Sheldon, his only sibling, is 85. And for the past 40 years, they've pretty much been on the outs.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: My father lives in Montreal, and Sheldon lives in Florida. And the last time they saw each other, over 20 years ago, was at their mother's funeral, where they had a fight over the details of the arrangements. Since then, they've hardly spoken.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: It worries me, because there's not a lot of time left. And I don't want my father to have regrets. And my father has a profound capacity for regret. My mother gave up trying to reunite them years ago, after many attempts. So I know that if I don't push him, no one else will.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: I'm not surprised that you're not jumping at the idea. But I'm a little surprised--

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: No.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: -- that you're as against the idea.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Yeah, time's passed. He hasn't shown much interest. So I'm respecting that, and I leave him alone.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: What he did do, was he called you on your 80th birthday, not so long ago.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Yeah. Yeah.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: And you felt good about that.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Yeah, because I called him on his 80th birthday.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: This kind of tit-for-tat accounting is what always gets in the way.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: You know what it is at this point, with him? I'll tell you what it is. I don't think it's even anger. He's past anger, and he's past any feelings of animosity. He's past that. He just doesn't care.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: You know, that's apathy. I mean, sometimes-- at least hate or love, they're emotions. Apathy is nothing.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: But you know what? Jonny, as a child, even when I was 10, when I was 9 and 8, I was crazy about him. We had a great-- you know, I loved him. He was the older brother. He was-- hello?

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Yeah, yeah, yeah, I'm listening.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: You know, I just looked up to him. And he had all the friends. Sometimes he'd take me along with him. And he was [AUDIO OUT]. [INAUDIBLE]. Somebody tried-- is somebody to call here, binging me here?

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: The most complicated question, the one I keep coming back to, is how did the bad blood begin? And there are many versions. An ill-fated trip to Montreal, where Sheldon felt slighted about having to stay in my father's basement. An ill-fated trip to New York, where my father felt slighted about having to stay in Sheldon's attic.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Rude words spoken to each other's wives. In one version of the story, Sheldon's refusal to bring a table to my bris almost resulted in my being circumcised on an ironing board. But in the version being told today, my father was asked by Sheldon to pay more than his fair share for their mother's funeral.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: And I said, you're always working some kind of an angle. So he got furious. He got furious. He started screaming into the phone, go to hell. Drop dead, bah, bah, bah. He was-- that was how that ended.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: But I feel he's the kind of guy, that he has angles like that, you know? He has angles. I always felt I was on the up-and-up with him, and he wasn't with me.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: If you got a stronger sense that he was interested in seeing you, then would you--

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Yes. Yes.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: You would be more inclined to see him?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: I wouldn't stay at his house though, that's out of the question.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: OK, quick sidebar. Anytime I've ever raised the prospect of visiting Sheldon, no matter how hypothetical the scenario, my father always makes a point of insisting how no matter what, he would not stay in Sheldon's house-- even if he was invited to. Which, I should point out, he never is.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: I wouldn't stay at his house.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: How come you-- [LAUGHS]

speaker: buzz goldstein

speaker: buzz goldstein

speaker: buzz goldstein

speaker: jonathan goldstein

speaker: buzz goldstein

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Hi.

utterance: That was quite a shock, getting your phone call. You said, Jon, and my hearing is not that great.

utterance: Sheldon now lives outside of Fort Lauderdale. But my few memories of him are from when he lived in upstate New York. I remember he lived in a trailer.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: I remember that he worked at a local prison, that he smoked cigars, that he looked a little like my father, but was hunched, like the world was weighing down on him. And he always wore this expression on his face that seemed to say, you got to be kidding me.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: You're keeping OK? You're keeping occupied?

speaker: sheldon goldstein

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Uh huh.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: sheldon goldstein

utterance: Case in point-- this is Sheldon accidentally swiping a portable microphone receiver off the kitchen table, and me trying to smooth things over.

utterance: Take this off, will you? It's annoying.

utterance: Here, just put it in your pocket there.

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: Just take it off, would you please? Thank you. Thank you.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: All right.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Over the next two days, my testes will flee like frightened cockroaches, upward, ascending to heights not seen since the bar mitzvah that Sheldon was not attending. While it's fun watching them reminisce, I'd say, that about 80% of my uncle Sheldon's stories about the good old days are filthy enough to make them virtually unbroadcastable. But here's one-- specially selected, and beeped for your delicate ears.

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: Wally Rosen. Wonder whatever became of him. He was a bum. Me and Wally Rosen were joining the weightlifting club. So you had to be tested for a rupture. I remember he put his hand [BLEEP]. I started laughing so hard, I [BLEEP] right in his [BLEEP]. [LAUGHS] Ay yay yay.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Over the years, I've seen my father in the role of husband, uncle, and grandfather. But I've never really seen him in the role of younger brother. How odd to see it now, at 80. He sits beside Sheldon, with this expression I've never seen on his face. It's wide-eyed, sweet, and deferential. But as the day wears on, Sheldon and Buzz begin to squabble over their memories, fighting over every little detail.

utterance: Remember the hullabaloo we had with hair dyer, that heavy-set girl?

speaker: buzz goldstein

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: I did.

speaker: buzz goldstein

utterance: I walked in on her.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: I never saw a dead body in my life, but I knew she was dead. Sure.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: So wait, so you found her, or you found her?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: I remember looking in on her room to see how she was doing. She was awfully quiet. [INTERPOSING VOICES]

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: [INAUDIBLE]. I found her, but let him take the credit.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: No, I'm not. [LAUGHS] Some credit.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: The whole afternoon is like this. Every subject, even their dead grandmother, somehow becomes fodder for another pissing match. They're burning up all this time with small talk, when what they need is some big talk. In particular, they need to address a story that I know holds a great deal of meaning for my father. It took place in 1939, on the day their mother left them. I've only ever heard the story from my father, never from Sheldon.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: I wanted to ask what you remember. What your perspective--

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: Well, I remember that time was when Pop was smacking her around, and she ran out in the hall. And her slip--

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Fighting in the hall.

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: And he was smacking her around.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Yeah, smacking her around.

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: She ran out.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: So what happened the next morning?

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: The next morning?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Yeah. Looked in her closet. Her clothes were gone. She left.

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: Ah.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: What happened after this, in my father's telling, is that his mother returned soon after she left, with a policeman in tow.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: And they came back to try to get you. They wanted you to come back with them.

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: And where were you?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: I was there, but they were trying to drag you out of the house. [LAUGHS]

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: They weren't trying to grab you out?

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: No, no, no. I guess they want my father and grandmother.

speaker: jonathan goldstein

And after a year, their mother returned. And together, Buzz and Sheldon grew up under the same roof, in the same bedroom, often sleeping under the same blankets, each knowing who the mother had chosen, and each having to do their best to carry on and live life with the burden of that knowledge.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: A couple times during the day, I ask them why they haven't spoken in so long. And they both insist, maybe out of embarrassment, that they do talk, just not often. But it isn't true. In fact, my father learned of Sheldon's wife's death many years after the fact-- and then, only from me.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Sheldon's daughter got in touch through Facebook, and we made a phone date, where she caught me up on her life and Sheldon's. And a few nights later, while over at my parents' for dinner, I told my father of his sister-in-law's death. There was a terrible look that fell across his face. One of sadness, but something else too, maybe shock over just how far he and Sheldon had drifted.

utterance: I found out about Judy-- about her death.

utterance: Who?

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Oh, it spread.

utterance: I don't know how you could take Canada all year around.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Yeah. Yeah.

speaker: jonathan goldstein

He'll say, "For how many years?"

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: But just then, I watch my father clench and unclench his jaw, as he does when he is brooding. I know he's trying to take the high road, trying not to ruin the evening.

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: What? $200.30? Are they kidding?

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Sheldon invites us back to his place for cookies. But my father says he isn't up for it.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: Goodnight.

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: Goodnight.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Goodnight.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: It's getting cold.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: As we walk through the restaurant parking lot to the car, my father is silent. I find myself feeling protective of him, like maybe encouraging this trip had been a bad idea, only making things worse. After midnight, lying awake in our hotel-- my father insisted we stay at one-- I lay in bed, thinking about that day in 1939, when my grandmother came back for Sheldon, not my father. For my father, not only did it push him away from Sheldon, making him feel jealous and resentful, but it also cast a shadow over the rest of his life, causing him to always feel passed over. He's mellowed with age. But as a kid, I saw it come out in all kinds of ways. Always sensitive to slights, ready for a fight at the smallest perceived offense. I wonder if there's a different way from my father to see things. If there is, the only living person in this world who can help is Sheldon. When their mom left, Sheldon was nine, my father, five. Sheldon would have understood a lot more than my father.

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Yesterday, Buzz and Sheldon talked like a couple of kids who used to play stick ball in the old neighborhood. Today, if me and my big, fat, meddling yap have any sway, they'll have a chance to talk as men-- as brothers, even. Because if not now, when?

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: Day two.

utterance: This is a damn good cigar.

But hearing Sheldon's take, it sounds like maybe their mother didn't come to take Sheldon because she loved him best, but simply because he needed more protecting from their father.

speaker: jonathan goldstein

speaker: sheldon goldstein
utterance: No.

speaker: buzz goldstein
utterance: No?

speaker: jonathan goldstein
utterance: The last time my father saw my grandfather in full health, my dad was visiting from Canada. My grandfather asked my father to drive him to the cemetery, to visit his parents' grave. And once there, my grandfather wept inconsolably.

utterance: They put a lot of the responsibility on him, that my dad should have been taking that responsibility. And he shouldered that.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: Biba Struja was in high school in Serbia when he learned he was different from other people.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: We talked about it through an interpreter. He was on the phone from Serbia. He said it was a rainy day. They were going in to weld gates and fences. And his friend touched the fence they were working on and got a shock.

ep-598.speaker: interpreter
ep-598.utterance: He told me not to touch anything because there was electricity there. But I touched it with my bare hand, and I didn't feel anything. Nothing happened.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: Nothing happened.

ep-598.speaker: interpreter
ep-598.utterance: So he didn't believe me that I didn't feel anything, that there was no electricity in the fence. So he touched it again, but he was shocked again.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: Then another guy touches the fence, and he was shocked. Biba sees this, and he thinks, oh, it's a prank. They're pretending.

ep-598.speaker: interpreter
ep-598.utterance: So I touched the fence with both hands again, and I didn't feel anything. And we started fighting. I didn't believe them, and they thought that I was lying.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: Biba has a genetic mutation where he doesn't sweat. That means his skin has a lot less water and so a higher resistance to electricity. He says he does not feel currents that would shock most of us. And scientists say, yeah, that might be possible. This super power does come with that huge downside of not sweating, ever. Having a body that cannot cool itself is really, really miserable.

ep-598.speaker: interpreter
ep-598.utterance: From May until September, I'm a dead man, basically.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: Because of the heat.

ep-598.speaker: interpreter
ep-598.utterance: Yes. I need to be next to an air conditioner all day, or I need to be in a wet t-shirt or next to water or something.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: But the biggest problem with having a special talent like a high resistance to electricity is figuring out what exactly you do with that talent. You can't just put on a costume and join the X-Men. Until the day that mankind is threatened by an alien race whose bodies are electric charges, you really aren't much use as a superhero. Biba's brother has the same genetic mutation, and he decided to do nothing with it. He stayed on the family farm.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: But Biba was sure there must be a way to monetize this. So he went into show business, created a little act doing electricity tricks, like this one-- he sticks a fork in each end of a hot dog, holds the hot dog in midair in front of his face, one hand on each fork, and then-- OK, it's not clear exactly what's going on or whether you actually need a genetic mutation to do this trick, but electricity is pumped through the forks and cooks the hot dog.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: This is from a really good film that was made about Biba called Battery Man, Biba saying, am I the fastest grill or not? It just takes a minute or so to cook a hot dog this way. He toured around Europe doing this act, mostly in discos, he says, sometimes on TV. It's not much of a living. He's got kids. So he supplements that with a job that also sounds like it's kind of a grind for him-- he does therapeutic massages with electricity, up to 20 a day.

ep-598.speaker: interpreter
ep-598.utterance: I have a certificate as an electrobiotherapist.

ep-598.speaker: ira glass
ep-598.utterance: In English, anyway, this word "electrobiotherapist" has the unusual distinction of producing not one hit when you Google it. Mostly, you're probably getting the picture-- Biba's special talent does not seem to make him very happy. When we talked, he complained about the injustice of being born in Serbia, where people don't understand his special gift. In the movie about him, he says sometimes his talent feels like a curse. But when I asked him about that, he said, we're all cursed.

ep-598.speaker: interpreter
